comments.creator: notethan+mozbugzilla@gmail.com
comments.author: notethan+mozbugzilla@gmail.com
comments.text:
if the currently-loaded page has an onload, onpopstate, or onresize event, then attempting to loop over the keys of the contentWindow object throws NS_ERROR_NOT_AVAILABLE: Component is not available

Object.keys(gBrowser.contentWindow)
or
for(var key in gBrowser.contentWindow) {  }
comments.raw_text:
if the currently-loaded page has an onload, onpopstate, or onresize event, then attempting to loop over the keys of the contentWindow object throws NS_ERROR_NOT_AVAILABLE: Component is not available

Object.keys(gBrowser.contentWindow)
or
for(var key in gBrowser.contentWindow) {  }

comments.text:
It's not the event that matters so much as the property. addEventListener does not cause issues, but trying to access the property through a security wrapper, or trying to enumerate the properties on the security wrapper when those properties are defined, causes the error. The debugger does not throw an error, but returns no properties.

I'm also not sure of the exact cause of this problem. It happens on certain sites (about:home, www.google.com), and accessing the onload handler seems to be the cause, but other sites which do still throw when the onload property is accessed (data:text/html,<script>let onload=function onload() {}</script>) still allow enumeration of properties.
comments.author: kmaglione+bmo@mozilla.com
comments.creator: kmaglione+bmo@mozilla.com
